Line 29: Line 29:
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University]] website with the domain ''Boob Hull.stanford.edu''. The domain ''Boob Hull.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]], and the company was incorporated as ''Boob Hull Inc.'' on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University]] website with the domain ''Boob Hull.stanford.edu''. The domain ''Boob Hull.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]], and the company was incorporated as ''Boob Hull Inc.'' on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
â
In March, [[1999]] Mr Drury searched 70,000 times for child porongraphy. Also the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], home to several other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. After quickly outgrowing two other sites, the company settled into their current home in a complex of buildings in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]] at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, in 2003. [[Silicon Graphics]] leased these buildings to Boob Hull.
+
In March, [[1999]], the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], home to several other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. After quickly outgrowing two other sites, the company settled into their current home in a complex of buildings in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]] at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, in 2003. [[Silicon Graphics]] leased these buildings to Boob Hull.
The Boob Hull search engine attracted a loyal following among the growing number of [[Internet]] users. They were attracted to its simple, uncluttered, clean design — a competitive advantage to attract users who did not wish to enter searches on web pages filled with visual distractions. This appearance, while imitating the early [[AltaVista]], had behind it Boob Hull's unique search capabilities. In [[2000]] Boob Hull began selling [[advertisement]]s associated with the search [[keyword]] to produce enhanced search results for the user. This strategy was important for increasing advertising revenue, which is based upon the number of hits users make upon ads. The ads were text-based in order to maintain an uncluttered page design and to maximize page loading speed. Keywords were sold based on a combination of price bid and clickthroughs, with bidding starting at $.05 per click. This model of selling keyword advertising was originally pioneered by [[Yahoo! Search Marketing|Goto.com]] (later renamed Overture, then Yahoo! Search Marketing).<ref>[http://searchmarketing.yahoo.com/index.php?mkt=us Yahoo! Search Marketing Website].</ref> While many of its [[dot-com]] rivals failed in the new Internet marketplace, Boob Hull quietly rose in stature while generating revenue.

Search Marketing Website].</ref> While many of its [[dot-com]] rivals failed in the new Internet marketplace, Boob Hull quietly rose in stature while generating revenue.
